lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six more body parts (head, ears, mouth, eyes, nose, neck) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show head/face flashcards. Say each word and ask: “Where is it?” Students point to the correct part on a picture or their body.
stretchStrategies: ❝Mystery Student Description❞ – Describe a classmate without saying their name (e.g., “He’s got big eyes and a small mouth”). The class guesses who it is. Students then take turns describing someone else.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about body parts using “He’s/She’s got…” and an adjective.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Point to a face in the SB. Ask: “What has she got?” Students say: “She’s got big eyes.” Drill with different adjectives.
stretchStrategies: ❝Mystery Student Description❞ – Describe a classmate without saying their name (e.g., “He’s got big eyes and a small mouth”). The class guesses who it is. Students then take turns describing someone else.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “He’s/She’s got ___.” to describe body parts.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write: “He’s got ___.” and “She’s got ___.” Students complete sentences orally using images or puppets.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
